_items.body:
• Own your key messages, especially the difficult ones


• Be open to hear things that you don’t like or want to hear


• Be vulnerable – share something of yourself
_items.title: BE COURAGEOUS

_items.body:
•Walk in the other person’s shoes


•Respect different perspectives


•Avoid making assumptions
_items.title: BE EMPATHETIC

_items.body:
• Give your undivided attention


• Ask more and better questions


• Listen to understand not just hear
_items.title: BE PRESENT
BE AWARE
_items.body:
• Know what you want to say and how you want to say it


• Understand how your mood and reactions impact others


• Recognise and calmly keep conversations on track

• Give the other person time to digest what you are saying


• Don’t be afraid to stay silent, or ask for more time to consider your response


• Listen for their perspective and for what you do not already know
_items.title: BE SILENT

_incorrect.final:
Thats not quite right.


Open questions are designed to require a full, meaningful answer. For example, "how do you..." or "why do you...".


Closed questions require a yes or a no response. Such as "when can you..." or "have you tried...".


Probing questions are open in nature, but are specific enough that the listener will respond with the information needed. For example, "What are your thoughts on the new store layout?"


Paraphrasing questions repeat back details heard to make sure the questioner has understood what the other person has communicated. For example, "So you are saying that...".


Leading questions direct the listener to answer a certain way, or consider a different perspective. For example, "Would you need this item gift wrapped?" (asked before a customer has decided to buy the product).


Hypothetical questions pose a scenario that is fictitious, to understand how the listener would act if the scenario were to come to fruition. For example, "How would you feel if...".


Reflective questions require the listener to reflect and share their thoughts on past experiences. "Tell me about your experience with...".

Well done, all these are correct. 

Open questions are designed to require a full, meaningful answer. For example, "how do you..." or "why do you...".


Closed questions require a yes or a no response. Such as "when can you..." or "have you tried...". 


Probing questions are open in nature, but are specific enough that the listener will respond with the information needed. For example, "What are your thoughts on the new store layout?"


Paraphrasing questions repeat back details heard to make sure the questioner has understood what the other person has communicated. For example, "So you are saying that...".


Leading questions direct the listener to answer a certain way, or consider a different perspective. For example, "Would you need this item gift wrapped?" (asked before a customer has decided to buy the product).


Hypothetical questions pose a scenario that is fictitious, to understand how the listener would act if the scenario were to come to fruition. For example, "How would you feel if...".


Reflective questions require the listener to reflect and share their thoughts on past experiences. "Tell me about your experience with...".

_items.text: How did you go with that task?
Have you had a lunch break yet?
Tell me more about what happened with that customer?
You’re saying you may need help to finish, is that right?

_items.text: If we get busy would you be able to work an extra shift?
Was the way you spoke to the customer was correct?
What are you learning from your current job challenges?
How did you find your first day?

_items.title: IDENTIFY THE KEY 'STAND OUT' WORDS
_items.body: “I’m having trouble with a person in my team. He can’t seem to be bothered."

_items.title: ASK ABOUT ONE OF THE KEY WORDS

_items.body: “He’s not as productive as he used to be."
_items.title: LISTEN FOR THE ANSWER
NOTICE THE NEW KEY WORD AND QUESTION IT

_items.body: “He gets less work done in a week and the quality has slipped too."
_items.title: LISTEN FOR THE ANSWER
NOTICE THE NEW KEY WORD AGAIN
_items.body: “Why do you think he is getting less work done?” or “Tell me about the slip in quality…”
Listen for the key words and ask about them until you reach a good understanding of the situation.
_items.title: LISTEN FOR THE KEY WORDS
